Could the greed of our politicians be catching on to our farmers here in NC? Farmers gotta take it if they can get it. Try farming and you'll find out why. They borrow money for seed, fertilizer, fuel, equipment, etc etc etc, hoping people will even buy what they plant. If they are REALLY lucky, the bugs and weather and sun don't ruin their crop. But if they have a bumper crop, they gotta hope their neighbor loses everything, or he'll have a bumper crop too - and too much product means the prices will plummet!! Then, he's got to harvest it and ship it to market, getting gouged and screwed at every turn by the haulers and railroads - and again he's got to beat his neighbor to market right at the instant his crop is coming ripe. If he's early, people won't buy because the flavor is wrong. If he's late, his neighbor has the market and his own crop begins to go bad and rot. Even if he gets top dollar, he'll be damned lucky to break even on all his loans and have enough to buy his kids Christmas. Then he has to take out a bunch of loans for seed and fertilizer and fuel, and start all over again - - Not too surprising that most of our fruits and vegetables come from outside the country, as farmers either give up and abandon the land, or subdivide it all up for houses - the final cash crop.... But a glut has even killed that market - - Why do I know this to be true? Because I ranched and farmed all my younger days with grandparents, uncles and a father that pretty much lost it all - hoping the next year would finally pay the bills - - That's why, if you have hundred or thousands of acres of land you're trying to farm, you're "acre rich, but dirt poor"! content: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: Sarge thanks for the heads up re the tomatoes, I've not had any luck growing tomatoes here. I went from putting them in the veg. garden to 5 gal buckets on the deck next to the house. I figured they'd get more sun and it would be warmer. It didn't help, I've used different varieties of tomatoes. I always used good potting soil and Miracle Grow fertilizer. I'm confused the bucket and the 2 in. holes. You fill the bucket with potting soil, then put the starts in the holes. If the soil is in the bucket, how do you get the starts in the holes? The soil will hold in the bucket and you poke your finger in and then the start. You can put enough potting soil in to cover the holes, put in the starts, punch the soil down around the starts from the inside working to hold it in place from the outside. Then fill the bucket two or three inches from the rim. You have to learn the watering technique for yourself. Too much and you can wash out the starts. Hole size is another preference. 1 in. holes work as well as two inch. The size of a tomato stalk is variable but the hole needs to be big enough to let it take water into the stem and not grow to choke itself off. Try painting the buckets a darker color, or get a blue or gray bucket. Dark plastic for the cold months and then take it off in the summer. Just a dark color to warm the soil. You can drape a clear plastic film over the bottom of the bucket to about 1 ft. below the bottom to ward off some frost. I went from putting them in the veg. garden to 5 gal buckets on the deck next to the house. I figured they'd get more sun and it would be warmer. It didn't help, I've used different varieties of tomatoes. I always used good potting soil and Miracle Grow fertilizer. I'm confused the bucket and the 2 in. holes. You fill the bucket with potting soil, then put the starts in the holes. If the soil is in the bucket, how do you get the starts in the holes?
reply: The soil will hold in the bucket and you poke your finger in and then the start. You can put enough potting soil in to cover the holes, put in the starts, punch the soil down around the starts from the inside working to hold it in place from the outside. Then fill the bucket two or three inches from the rim. You have to learn the watering technique for yourself. Too much and you can wash out the starts. Hole size is another preference. 1 in. holes work as well as two inch. The size of a tomato stalk is variable but the hole needs to be big enough to let it take water into the stem and not grow to choke itself off. Try painting the buckets a darker color, or get a blue or gray bucket. Dark plastic for the cold months and then take it off in the summer. Just a dark color to warm the soil. You can drape a clear plastic film over the bottom of the bucket to about 1 ft. below the bottom to ward off some frost.
